China's foreign exchange reserves fell to $3.33 trillion at the end of December from $3.44 trillion last month, the lowest since December 2012. The month-on-month change of -3.1% is the largest drop since 2004. China’s foreign exchange reserves have dived -16.5% since the peak in June 2014 ($3.99 trillion). We expect FX reserves / M2 to be around 15% at the end of 2015, and the government should closely monitor the alarming situation of capital flight.

11:10 am
BE

 Gold reserves edged up to $60.2 billion in December, from $59.5 billion a month earlier.
 SDR didn’t stem outflows in December: As we expected, the inclusion of RMB in the IMF Special Drawing Rights basket (SDR) has seemingly offered no help to prop up the RMB. In fact, market could have strengthened bets on depreciation of Yuan after knowing the PBoC has limited its interventions after the SDR inclusion, which would only exacerbate capital flee.
 CNH-CNY spread has widened: The yuan faces strong depreciation pressure offshore as the market is betting on the down side. This is reflected in the widened gap between CNY and CNH to an average of 660bps in December from 300bps in November. Further depreciation in the RMB would quicken capital outflows that drain foreign reserves.

BE

 Volatile equity market adds fuel to the flight: Nosedives of Chinese equity market in early January 2016 would offer no help but further speed up capital flee, we expect China’s foreign reserves to drop further to $3.20 trillion in January 2016.
 Continuous fall in FX reserves may trigger RRR cut near Chinese New Year: The PBoC issued RMB 130 billion 7D reserve repo at 2.25% after the A-shares triggered the circuit breaker on the first working day of the year, which is surely a way to comfort market. Similarly, continuous fall in reserves would trigger an RRR cut, when liquidity usually becomes tighter near long holidays, to replenish liquidity in the market.

BE

Amid the backdrop of weakening growth, equity market plunge and widening spread between CNH and CNY, the story is clear - the trend that China is losing its foreign reserves will continue (if not accelerate) notwithstanding a still substantial current account surplus. It is expected reserves would lower to $3.20 trillion in January 2016.

What is happening to the equity market?

“China’s equity market has hit the daily 7% loss limit today for the second time in the first week of 2016. We think two drivers are leading the weakness. First is supply. The stock market artificially stabilized in 2015 because the government prevented selling. This week the selling bans were to be removed and showed that current prices were too expensive for buyers to soak up the extra supply coming onto the market. Second, the currency weakness is hurting the equity market. Theoretically, with very little foreign ownership, currency weakness should not translate into domestic equity market weakness. However, CNY weakness and more importantly, the People's Bank of China (PBoC) allowing CNY to reflect weakness in economic fundamentals, send a more accurate signal on the state of the Chinese economy and a bigger threshold for the government to accept pain. The floor is getting lower.”

11:12 am

Why does the spread matter?

“The CNH market is China’s proxy foreign exchange market, which are not subject to capital controls. Individuals and corporates use the CNH market to hedge onshore CNY exposure. If the spread widens and CNH does not track the onshore CNY value, the CNH market becomes useless. When the IMF included CNY in the SDR basket as one of the ‘elite’ reserve currencies of the world, it specifically mentioned that that CNY/CNH spread should be limited because CNH market was the door connecting offshore to onshore market or opening in China’s capital account. If the spread widens, the door is dysfunctional and means the capital account is not opening up, making CNY less of an ‘elite’ currency and losing reserve status.”

PM

Is this currency war?

“It’s looking more like it. CNY weakness since August 11 has moved in step with weakness in the Nominal Effective Exchange Rate (NEER) meaning, CNY is cheaper across the board, not just versus USD. Yes, it’s playing catch up since CNY NEER strengthened in 2013 and 2014 but there is no doubt CNY is gaining from its competitors.”

PM

What is our view going forward on CNY and Chinese equities?

“CNY and Chinese equities will move like developed market currencies and equity markets. Only with fundamental improvement will CNY and Chinese equities recover. Our economic outlook is still for further weakening. Incoming data is showing that the main supporter of growth in 2015, services, are showing signs of weakness, following manufacturing. Furthermore, recent government announcement emphasises reducing excess capacity in heavy industry such as steel and cement, which will put more pressure on the labor market and consumption. Hence, we still prefer to be short CNY and CNH and we are short TWD as a proxy trade. As stated above, 6.83 is target on CNY but stronger USD or weaker Euro can weaken it further. We also recommended long JPY vs CNH but we understand that it has moved and suggest waiting for a pull back before entering. Equity outlook is weak so we are recommending relative value trades where we like Philippines relative to Korea.”

With PBoC allowing for more volatility and weakness in CNY, this transmission mechanism will only amplify. For those of you outside of Asia (e.g. US), please get ready for more contagion. BE

As could be expected the CFO provided a robust advocacy of the deal highlighting that the BG assets remain exactly what Shell wanted after a three-year clean up period and that even in the prevailing oil price environment the number of other opportunities is low. The commitment to the dividend remains and although acknowledging that oil prices could go lower from here, the deal is based on what both we and RDS see as a low probability of the price averaging below $60/bl over the next 15 years. It is clear to us that the deal will strengthen the Shell portfolio with the combined entity free cash flow positive in a $50/bl environment but the current 8% spread between the implied offer price for BG and the current share price does suggest more uncertainty over the successful completion of the deal than we ourselves see. We rate both stocks Overweight.

BE

Oil price weakness near term, but probability of averaging $60/bl for next 15 years is low: Simon Henry repeated comments from a media interview earlier in the week that in the short term the oil price could well continue to fall from current levels to below $20/bl, or at least that’s what the Shell traders are telling their CFO. That is however only a short-term view and CFO Henry provided a reminder that spare capacity in the oil market remains low and with Non-OPEC supply set to fall this year and demand likely to be up 1-1.2mb/d in 2016 this spare capacity essentially gets used up by the end of 2016/early 2017. Yes, there remains a stock buffer, but this can disappear very quickly and as a result even a short disruption to production could materially change people’s view points on the oil price. Essentially the message was one that the short-term and long-term economics are different and that as a result the probability of the oil price averaging below $60/bl for 15 years is low, even if it takes a couple of years to return to that level.

11:30 am
BE

Financial commitments remain: In that context the commitment to the dividend, the $30bn asset disposal plan and share repurchase plan remain. Given the oil price and that RDS is at the edge of the criteria for the rating agencies, Simon Henry did highlight that he wouldn’t be surprised by a ratings downgrade, but that this would have a relatively minimal effect on the company. If the price stays where it is the first response is to extend the scrip dividend programme, then push the buy-back back with the dividend the last thing that would be looked at. In terms of divestments, there won’t be a fire sale of assets but at least a third of the planned sales could be downstream, where prices are likely to be better.

BE

Strategy update in June, with details in October: Although plans are not confirmed at the moment it is likely that having operated the assets for three-four months the group will be able to provide an update on progress in June, although a full two-three year strategic plan is unlikely until later in the year – potentially September/October. The initial focus will be on safety and then synergy capture and then value capture.
